title: Kain panjang

  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features zigzag bands decorated with stylised animals and birds. The various segments are also decorated with geometric motifs and foliage designs. There is a signature on the top-left of the batik kain panjang.

  subject_terms_1: depictions (visual works) Peranakan lozenges cultural diffusion foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: The entire kain panjang is covered with zigzag bands decorated with unusual animals and birds
 and decorative motifs.  The motifs are rendered in Chinese style although Javanese elements
 such as the ancient parang (or sword) motif
 are also present.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendromartono Pekalongan Java”.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: The entire kain panjang is covered with zigzag bands decorated with unusual animals and birds, and decorative motifs.  The motifs are rendered in Chinese style although Javanese elements, such as the ancient parang (or sword) motif, are also present.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendromartono Pekalongan Java”.
